description: Access is the database application within the Microsoft Office suite.  Many businesses, large and small, use Access to store large amounts of information. Just like building a a strong house, you must have a solid foundation. We start from the very beginning discussing how to plan a database, introducing basic terminology and key concepts of relational database design, and exploring the Access Interface. Then we dive more in depth into each object in an Access databases - tables, queries, forms, and reports.  This series is targeted for users who want to get started in Access or users that want a refresher on Access essentials.  Access is a Windows only product and only available as a local installation.

Then we dive more in depth into each object in an Access databases - tables, queries, forms, and reports.  This series is targeted for users who want to get started in Access or users that want a refresher on Access essentials.  Access is a Windows only product and only available as a local installation.
name: Access 2016 Essentials
subtitle: Database application

episodes.description: Access is the database application within the Microsoft Office suite. Many businesses, large and small, use Access to store large amounts of information. Just like building a a strong house, you must have a solid foundation. We start from the very beginning discussing how to plan a database, introducing basic terminology and key concepts of relational database design, and exploring the Access Interface. Then we dive more in depth into each object in an Access databases - tables, queries, forms, and reports. This series is targeted for users who want to get started in Access or users that want a refresher on Access essentials. Access is a Windows only product and only available as a local installation.
episodes.title: Overview

episodes.description: The dynamic dou of Vonne and Ronnie are back together to bring you Access 2016. In this episode, they review the basic question of what is Access, where it belongs in the Office suite, and other introductory topics.
episodes.title: Introduction to Access

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne introduce the concept of a database with a great analogy - laundry! They discuss the importance of organizing data and how the data relates to one another. They also discuss how Excel and Access differ in how they interact with data. They then take a trip down memory lane with examples of analog databases.
episodes.title: What is a Database

episodes.description: Ronnie and Vonne define and explain key terms in general databases and Access.
episodes.title: Database Terminology

episodes.description: Ronnie and Vonne had so much fun defining terms, they had to make a part 2! They continue to explain key terms in general databases and Access.
episodes.title: Database Terminology Part 2

episodes.description: Don't know where to begin in building a database in Access? Luckily, Access has templates to get you going.  Ronnie and Vonne explore creating a template database and indentify what Acccess creates for us.
episodes.title: Getting Started in Access

episodes.description: Vonne and Ronnie explore the Access interface. They identify the title bar, quick access toolbar, ribbon, status bar, and navigation pane.
episodes.title: Access Interface and Navigation

episodes.description: Prior proper planning prevents poor performance. Vonne and Ronnie talk about the importance of planning out a database and review basic concepts of relational database design.
episodes.title: Planning and Database Design

episodes.description: Vonne and Ronnie continue their discussion about planning a database.  Specifically, they review how they determined the fields needed in their tables for the show's database. They also touch upon the concept of data normalization.
episodes.title: Planning and Database Design Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Ronnie create their first table in a new database. They create fields and determine data types in the design view. They also review the field properties. Lastly, they enter in records in the datasheet view.
episodes.title: Creating Tables: Manual Data Entry
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.256 --> 00:00:16.078
Hello everyone and welcome to another
exciting edition of OfficeProTV.

3
00:00:16.078 --> 00:00:17.544
I'm your host Vonne Smith and

4
00:00:17.544 --> 00:00:21.510
we are continuing on with our
Access 2016 Essentials show.

5
00:00:21.510 --> 00:00:25.970
In this episode, we're going to be
creating tables, the old-fashioned way,

6
00:00:25.970 --> 00:00:27.625
manual data entry.

7
00:00:27.625 --> 00:00:33.595
[LAUGH] And here to help us is
Mr Ronnie Wong, hello, how are you?

8
00:00:33.595 --> 00:00:36.720
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] I am doing fine, Vonne.

9
00:00:36.720 --> 00:00:39.410
Yeah, it is a little bit difficult
with the R and the W there.

10
00:00:39.410 --> 00:00:42.717
They tend to juxtapose, and there we go,
and we have the different name.

11
00:00:42.717 --> 00:00:44.370
>> [LAUGH]
>> But, overall though, Vonne,

12
00:00:44.370 --> 00:00:49.480
grateful to be here on OfficeProTV as
we get started in working with Access.

13
00:00:49.480 --> 00:00:53.990
And the beginning foundation of that,
of course, is creating tables, okay?

14
00:00:53.990 --> 00:00:58.400
Now, remember that in previous episodes,
we did talk about using templates,

15
00:00:58.400 --> 00:01:01.340
and they were fine,
they'll do exactly what you need to.

16
00:01:01.340 --> 00:01:03.930
You don't ever have even to
worry about creating tables.

17
00:01:03.930 --> 00:01:06.960
But once you do that,
you also have to start entering in data.

18
00:01:06.960 --> 00:01:10.640
And the manual data entry
is probably going to

19
00:01:10.640 --> 00:01:14.740
be the way that it's going to work for
you the majority of the time.

20
00:01:14.740 --> 00:01:18.164
In other words, you're either gonna be
manually typing in the data yourself.

21
00:01:18.164 --> 00:01:20.699
Or you're gonna set up Access,
of course, or

22
00:01:20.699 --> 00:01:23.120
somebody else to enter
data into it as well.

23
00:01:23.120 --> 00:01:26.734
So we're gonna show you that process and
how a database designer would

24
00:01:26.734 --> 00:01:29.808
probably enter in data, and
let's say like, dummy data.

25
00:01:29.808 --> 00:01:33.506
So that we can test out the database and
see how it works in the way that we want

26
00:01:33.506 --> 00:01:37.450
it to, and verify that all the fields
are filling in the way that we want.

27
00:01:37.450 --> 00:01:40.840
And if we have to make some adjustments,
this is the time to do it,

28
00:01:40.840 --> 00:01:46.460
before we ever put any real production
data into our Access database.

29
00:01:46.460 --> 00:01:48.660
So testing is a key part of it,

30
00:01:48.660 --> 00:01:51.670
understanding the planning is
actually going to help you out right.

31
00:01:51.670 --> 00:01:52.830
The better that you plan,

32
00:01:52.830 --> 00:01:56.500
the less that you have to worry about
some of these other issues creeping in

33
00:01:56.500 --> 00:02:00.280
as you're now gonna work specifically
with Access to get started, okay?

34
00:02:00.280 --> 00:02:01.980
Especially on creating the tables.

35
00:02:01.980 --> 00:02:03.990
So Vonne, that is where we're going.

36
00:02:03.990 --> 00:02:05.480
We're gonna head right into Access,

37
00:02:05.480 --> 00:02:08.990
and make sure that we get started here,
and do what we need to do.

38
00:02:08.990 --> 00:02:11.410
And we'll start and bring in some data and
see what happens, all right?

39
00:02:11.410 --> 00:02:15.930
>> And we're using the table that we
actually used in our planning episode.

40
00:02:15.930 --> 00:02:20.263
All the fields that we determined that we
need, we're gonna use that as our baseline

41
00:02:20.263 --> 00:02:23.205
for this particular episode,
and see where it takes us.

42
00:02:23.205 --> 00:02:25.227
>> And then it's gonna be
important that we do that and

43
00:02:25.227 --> 00:02:26.550
that we understand the process.

44
00:02:26.550 --> 00:02:29.860
So we're gonna take it slow
at this particular point.

45
00:02:29.860 --> 00:02:33.600
Because understanding that process and
making sure that it's done

46
00:02:33.600 --> 00:02:38.230
during the planning phase, that was kind
of fun for us as we went through it.

47
00:02:38.230 --> 00:02:41.950
But now, we need to understand how do we
get that and translate it into Access.

48
00:02:41.950 --> 00:02:44.410
And then, what are some of
the details we need to make sure of.

49
00:02:44.410 --> 00:02:47.650
And then going back through, double
checking again that we've met all those

50
00:02:47.650 --> 00:02:49.400
principles, are gonna help us out, too.

51
00:02:49.400 --> 00:02:52.270
>> So we're probably gonna start
with a blank database this time

52
00:02:52.270 --> 00:02:54.100
instead of using any of those templates.

53
00:02:54.100 --> 00:02:57.170
We're gonna start from scratch and
then make our own tables.

54
00:02:57.170 --> 00:02:58.450
Is that step number one?

55
00:02:58.450 --> 00:03:02.120
>> That is gonna be step number one that
we are going to take a look at to do.

56
00:03:02.120 --> 00:03:09.075
So let's go ahead and see right here on
my desktop, I've selected Access 2016.

57
00:03:09.075 --> 00:03:11.610
From this point, you can't just say,
I'm gonna get started.

58
00:03:11.610 --> 00:03:14.440
Remember that everything in Access
really begins with a template.

59
00:03:14.440 --> 00:03:17.770
Even a blank database
that has nothing in it

60
00:03:17.770 --> 00:03:21.580
essentially is the basis of what we have.

61
00:03:21.580 --> 00:03:24.840
And, of course,
choosing an appropriate database name.

62
00:03:24.840 --> 00:03:29.145
So we are gonna call this one, as much
as I don't want to type this in, okay,

63
00:03:29.145 --> 00:03:30.563
DancingDogs.

64
00:03:30.563 --> 00:03:32.197
[LAUGH]
>> Yes.

65
00:03:32.197 --> 00:03:36.222
>> DancingDogsinc.

66
00:03:36.222 --> 00:03:40.924
[LAUGH] Yes, I actually did type that in,
and yes, I'm a little less masculine for

67
00:03:40.924 --> 00:03:42.996
it at this point, but here we go.

68
00:03:42.996 --> 00:03:43.886
>> It's gonna get better too.

69
00:03:43.886 --> 00:03:44.470
[LAUGH]
>> I know,

70
00:03:44.470 --> 00:03:46.620
yeah, that's what's scary, okay?

71
00:03:46.620 --> 00:03:48.695
So, I'm gonna click OK, and there we go.

72
00:03:48.695 --> 00:03:54.350
Okay, so, we have now created
the database file itself, okay?

73
00:03:54.350 --> 00:03:55.260
And this is important.

74
00:03:55.260 --> 00:03:56.842
Remember that Access,

75
00:03:56.842 --> 00:04:02.313
it doesn't keep the database in multiple
different files, as far as 16 parts.

76
00:04:02.313 --> 00:04:05.110
And you have to worry about each
of those parts getting corrupted.

77
00:04:05.110 --> 00:04:08.200
Everything is stored as a single file,
which makes it incredibly portable.

78
00:04:08.200 --> 00:04:12.765
From this point as it remains, actually
relatively big or small, I can move it

79
00:04:12.765 --> 00:04:17.346
from my laptop over to Vonne's laptop
just by simply copying the file over to.

80
00:04:17.346 --> 00:04:20.570
And then Vonne can do the thing
that she needs to do.

81
00:04:20.570 --> 00:04:22.830
And we are off and ready to go, okay?

82
00:04:22.830 --> 00:04:27.050
So once we get to this point and
we select that blank template, okay,

83
00:04:27.050 --> 00:04:29.990
we're gonna start adding
in a new object here.

84
00:04:29.990 --> 00:04:32.020
And we got a couple of
things that we can do.

85
00:04:32.020 --> 00:04:34.251
It gives us by default table number 1.

86
00:04:34.251 --> 00:04:37.705
>> Yeah, it's gonna say that,
that's what it always does when you start

87
00:04:37.705 --> 00:04:40.425
a new database,
is that it opens up a blank new Table1.

88
00:04:40.425 --> 00:04:48.120
And it also, it's opened up in that area
that we're calling, that design pane.

89
00:04:48.120 --> 00:04:50.350
I know it's not design pane, it's just-
>> This is our data sheet view.

90
00:04:50.350 --> 00:04:53.547
>> Okay, yes, the data sheet view in our
work area, we'll just call it that way.

91
00:04:53.547 --> 00:04:56.690
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, now, there are two things.

92
00:04:56.690 --> 00:05:01.399
When we start talking about the idea
of creating a table manually, you can,

93
00:05:01.399 --> 00:05:04.420
and you can see right up here at the top.

94
00:05:04.420 --> 00:05:07.880
If I don't have anything else,
and I don't know how to start,

95
00:05:07.880 --> 00:05:13.600
I can simply take my data and
start to enter it in right here, okay?

96
00:05:13.600 --> 00:05:15.010
Now you might go, well, how do I do that?

97
00:05:15.010 --> 00:05:15.960
You just type it in.

98
00:05:15.960 --> 00:05:17.639
I'm not gonna do this,
but you just type it in.

99
00:05:17.639 --> 00:05:20.945
And then you move on to the next cell and
you move on to the next cell and

100
00:05:20.945 --> 00:05:23.170
you continually type in the data.

101
00:05:23.170 --> 00:05:26.180
And you can begin building
your table that way, okay?

102
00:05:26.180 --> 00:05:29.860
They already have what they call their
own ID field which will be an auto number

103
00:05:29.860 --> 00:05:32.890
field to generate just a unique ID for
you.

104
00:05:32.890 --> 00:05:38.732
You don't really have to do any
real designing in that part, okay?

105
00:05:38.732 --> 00:05:42.279
Now once you set that up, you're gonna see
that it's gonna generate unusual table

106
00:05:42.279 --> 00:05:44.840
names for
you when you start doing other things.

107
00:05:44.840 --> 00:05:48.410
So we are going to control this
process a little bit better.

108
00:05:48.410 --> 00:05:52.510
And the way that we do that, of course,
is that we're gonna switch the views.

109
00:05:52.510 --> 00:05:56.730
And we're gonna set up the fields that
we want to appear in this first table

110
00:05:56.730 --> 00:06:00.100
that we are gonna call products,
is what's gonna happen, all right?

111
00:06:00.100 --> 00:06:02.915
So the way that we change
over to the design view,

112
00:06:02.915 --> 00:06:06.827
at least the way I'm going to do it,
is over on the left-hand side,

113
00:06:06.827 --> 00:06:10.346
I have the icon for
the different View buttons that are here.

114
00:06:10.346 --> 00:06:12.830
And I'm gonna select Design View.

115
00:06:12.830 --> 00:06:17.850
And once I do this, it's gonna ask,
what do I want the table name to be?

116
00:06:17.850 --> 00:06:20.310
The great thing is,
we've already set this up and

117
00:06:20.310 --> 00:06:24.899
we already went through the process,
the planning, so, I'm gonna add in tbl.

118
00:06:26.400 --> 00:06:31.045
Let me see if I can zoom in as I'm typing
here, and unlock my mouse to do this,

119
00:06:31.045 --> 00:06:34.410
tblProducts.

120
00:06:34.410 --> 00:06:37.630
Remember, I've also said this
in previous episodes as well,

121
00:06:37.630 --> 00:06:40.890
you don't have to do it this way,
but the convention is simple.

122
00:06:40.890 --> 00:06:45.690
Make sure that table names are normally
gonna be named as a plural,

123
00:06:45.690 --> 00:06:48.110
is what you're actually
gonna end up seeing here.

124
00:06:48.110 --> 00:06:50.720
Click OK, and there it is.

125
00:06:50.720 --> 00:06:53.350
I have now begun and I've created this.

126
00:06:53.350 --> 00:06:56.510
And you see it switched
the actual table name.

127
00:06:56.510 --> 00:06:57.850
Navigation pane is still here.

128
00:06:57.850 --> 00:07:00.560
I'm gonna take up some of that real
estate by collapsing the shutter

129
00:07:00.560 --> 00:07:01.850
bar is what they call it.

130
00:07:01.850 --> 00:07:05.420
And there is the navigation
pane kinda collapsed down so

131
00:07:05.420 --> 00:07:07.630
it gives us a little bit
more room to work with.

132
00:07:07.630 --> 00:07:09.840
So let's explore this
particular view just for

133
00:07:09.840 --> 00:07:12.470
a moment, Vonne,
before we get started here, okay?

134
00:07:12.470 --> 00:07:15.875
So, this is where people,
when they're playing around and

135
00:07:15.875 --> 00:07:19.949
they haven't gotten any kind of pointer or
direction about doing this,

136
00:07:19.949 --> 00:07:23.719
they may think that this is where
they start adding in data, okay?

137
00:07:23.719 --> 00:07:25.656
Why?
It looks a bit like Excel, okay?

138
00:07:25.656 --> 00:07:28.857
And don't me get wrong, there's not
thousands of columns or anything,

139
00:07:28.857 --> 00:07:32.100
it looks like three columns and
you start adding in information.

140
00:07:32.100 --> 00:07:34.158
And all of a sudden,
you get to the second field and

141
00:07:34.158 --> 00:07:36.418
you realize you can't add
in anything really, okay?

142
00:07:36.418 --> 00:07:39.440
And that's because this field
actually includes a drop down.

143
00:07:39.440 --> 00:07:42.610
So now you're a little bit more
stunned and then you realize, okay?

144
00:07:42.610 --> 00:07:46.059
So what are we doing here in the Design
View as we're setting up the structure for

145
00:07:46.059 --> 00:07:46.583
the table?

146
00:07:46.583 --> 00:07:50.237
We're essentially going to assign
underneath the field name here,

147
00:07:50.237 --> 00:07:52.634
remember that fields means columns, okay?

148
00:07:52.634 --> 00:07:56.238
We're gonna set those names up
over here on the left-hand side,

149
00:07:56.238 --> 00:07:58.211
is what's gonna end up happening.

150
00:07:58.211 --> 00:08:00.582
Then you also want a data type.

151
00:08:00.582 --> 00:08:03.483
Notice on the right-hand side,
it gives you a description and

152
00:08:03.483 --> 00:08:05.450
it says optional, okay?

153
00:08:05.450 --> 00:08:10.440
If you do this and you know that
multiple people are possibly going to be

154
00:08:10.440 --> 00:08:14.440
working on the infrastructure of your
database, in other words, the design and

155
00:08:14.440 --> 00:08:17.890
adding in stuff, the more information
you can include at the beginning,

156
00:08:17.890 --> 00:08:20.245
especially in the description,
is going to help.

157
00:08:20.245 --> 00:08:23.150
They're not going to wonder why
did you put this field in here?

158
00:08:23.150 --> 00:08:24.530
What is this about?

159
00:08:24.530 --> 00:08:27.620
Adding in those descriptions
are really helpful at times,

160
00:08:27.620 --> 00:08:30.470
especially when you have tons of fields.

161
00:08:30.470 --> 00:08:34.150
And you know that you have to actually
manage and do and you keep them separated.

162
00:08:34.150 --> 00:08:37.370
You end up seeing that some people
actually have two or three tables.

163
00:08:37.370 --> 00:08:40.391
And for one reason or another,
they name the table or

164
00:08:40.391 --> 00:08:42.596
the fields almost identical, okay?

165
00:08:42.596 --> 00:08:45.661
And each of those tables, they've
named them exactly the same thing and

166
00:08:45.661 --> 00:08:49.040
here it gives you a chance to make sure
that you specify exactly what you need to.

167
00:08:49.040 --> 00:08:52.700
But that field is not super important and
that's why they call it optional.

168
00:08:52.700 --> 00:08:57.450
I like it because it really does help me
to go back and I can look at design view

169
00:08:57.450 --> 00:09:01.030
and logically, I can work out why
that field is in that table, okay?

170
00:09:01.030 --> 00:09:03.460
So simply, when we start here, okay?

171
00:09:03.460 --> 00:09:06.680
I've got a couple of things that
I can do at this point, okay?

172
00:09:06.680 --> 00:09:11.820
Which is, I can accept the default
ID field which it generated and

173
00:09:11.820 --> 00:09:12.790
then the auto number.

174
00:09:12.790 --> 00:09:15.194
I can also rename this one if I want to.

175
00:09:15.194 --> 00:09:18.840
Now Vonne, since we actually did
create the data, did we actually

176
00:09:18.840 --> 00:09:22.390
do an auto number or did we actually
choose our own ID, do you remember?

177
00:09:22.390 --> 00:09:23.660
>> We decided that we were.

178
00:09:23.660 --> 00:09:24.866
We're on the products, right?

179
00:09:24.866 --> 00:09:26.409
>> Right.
>> Yes, well we wanted to have

180
00:09:26.409 --> 00:09:27.880
the item number.

181
00:09:27.880 --> 00:09:32.256
And that's also like on the record that
we're looking at, there's like that little

182
00:09:32.256 --> 00:09:35.983
key off to the side, so they were
already designated as the primary key.

183
00:09:35.983 --> 00:09:36.902
>> Right.

184
00:09:36.902 --> 00:09:40.812
>> And since we know that the primary
key is that unique identifier,

185
00:09:40.812 --> 00:09:43.900
then we would want to have
that as the item number.

186
00:09:43.900 --> 00:09:45.062
>> Right, yep.

187
00:09:45.062 --> 00:09:47.962
So you've got a couple of things
that we can do here on this primary

188
00:09:47.962 --> 00:09:49.080
key value as well.

189
00:09:49.080 --> 00:09:49.875
So let me do this.

190
00:09:49.875 --> 00:09:52.041
So let me kind of get
rid of this right now.

191
00:09:52.041 --> 00:09:54.068
And then, let's see.

192
00:09:55.217 --> 00:09:56.360
Yeah, we'll go ahead and do that.

193
00:09:56.360 --> 00:09:58.266
And we'll set our own primary key, okay?

194
00:09:58.266 --> 00:10:00.090
So that way we're not
gonna confuse anybody.

195
00:10:00.090 --> 00:10:02.203
>> Yeah.
But it's also good to point out that

196
00:10:02.203 --> 00:10:03.431
if you are using that.

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Ronnie help you to understand relationships between tables.  They discuss the most common types of table relationships. Using Access, they show how to make those relationships work.

>> Okay.

>> Yeah, so

it really does give you all those

What you're gonna find out, especially if

Vonn, in doing this, even though you

I'm just gonna do this, cuz you

[LAUGH]
>> I think you just kind of drove

You build all of your field,
your tables, your relationship.

Maybe put two, three,

>> Or, records, sorry.

>> Four records in each one, and then run

but you wanna make sure it works on four-
>> Yes.

548

>> Rather than 400,000.

>> Correct.
>> Cuz then you're gonna really,

551

>> Yes, yeah.

552

>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

553

>> But it really is,
it's important that we do that.

554
00:29:54.135 --> 00:29:55.415
So once everything is done and

00:29:55.415 --> 00:29:58.725
we don't have sample data, we've gotta
populate some sample data into it.

556
00:29:58.725 --> 00:30:01.015
But then we can run those queries.

557
00:30:01.015 --> 00:30:02.695
It's at that point we'll

not the relationships that we

00:30:07.030 --> 00:30:11.350
or whether we need to readjust some of

00:30:11.350 --> 00:30:12.845
So don't be scared and go,

561
00:30:12.845 --> 00:30:16.492
crud it didn't work let me just axe

562
00:30:16.492 --> 00:30:20.534
Go back and we'll take a look at that
in our, as we do some queries here.

563
00:30:20.534 --> 00:30:22.936
So Vonne, thatt's pretty much it for
what we have.

564
00:30:22.936 --> 00:30:26.161
>> Wow, so we need to make sure
we build our house strong, and if

the foundation isn't set or poured right,
we're gonna have to go do another one.

566
00:30:30.610 --> 00:30:33.860
I don't know how I'm pulling
out references of construction.

567
00:30:33.860 --> 00:30:35.765
>> [LAUGH]
>> I am getting ready to remodel my

568
00:30:35.765 --> 00:30:37.148
kitchen so maybe-
>> Well there you go, sure.

569
00:30:37.148 --> 00:30:39.419
>> That's why I'm thinking about that,
and being like gosh,

this is gonna take a while [LAUGH].

571
00:30:40.589 --> 00:30:44.050
Well, anyways, thank you so much for

572
00:30:44.050 --> 00:30:47.844
It's driving a lot of these points home

573

thing for you, and lots of planning,
and lots of relationship building.

574

So, [LAUGH] we're gonna go ahead and
wrap this episode up, and

575

then we'll go ahead and

576

So signing off for Office ProTV,

00:31:04.071 --> 00:31:07.729

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Ronnie introduce queries in Access. They review the different types of queries available and run a simple select query through the query wizard.
episodes.title: Creating Queries for Testing Desgin

So this is a very important part,

So Vonne, let's kind of just take a very

At that point, we went into Access of

So, at that point, we actually now

At this stage, there's two things

Okay, one which is gonna

You could have gotten

And this is not to frighten you or

>> He said okay, you're gonna go ahead and

And, of course, he helped me

49
00:02:41.080 --> 00:02:41.924
>> It did work.

50
00:02:41.924 --> 00:02:46.922
>> And it wasn't until we got
into this area where we actually

51
00:02:46.922 --> 00:02:50.395
had found a couple flaws here and there.

52
00:02:50.395 --> 00:02:55.393
Few things were great, but
the possibility of it working our

53
00:02:55.393 --> 00:03:00.883
flawlessly every single time,
it's a small margin right there.

54
00:03:00.883 --> 00:03:05.546
So we've kind of incorporated our
issues that we've found throughout

55
00:03:05.546 --> 00:03:06.718
these episodes.

56
00:03:06.718 --> 00:03:08.777
This one we're gonna have,
it's gonna work perfectly.

57
00:03:08.777 --> 00:03:09.819
>> Right.
>> Right, yeah, and

58
00:03:09.819 --> 00:03:11.014
we've planned this for you all, okay?

59

So we're gonna make sure that this one,

[LAUGH] I've never been so excited to

[LAUGH]
>> Well, the neat thing is this right,

I don't want to give you

And Vonne and
I don't wanna give you a false impression.

66

If you did everything the way that we

67
00:03:38.180 --> 00:03:42.391
Because you're very first time you're

68
00:03:42.391 --> 00:03:46.143
You're likely to kind of do things
that logically seem to make sense, but

69
00:03:46.143 --> 00:03:48.152
Access goes I don't like that, okay.

70
00:03:48.152 --> 00:03:49.977
And you're just gonna have
to learn from that, and

00:03:49.977 --> 00:03:52.405
that's what we're doing here is

And we included it in because

I followed exactly what they said and

You're gonna see that if you

some of it will work out perfectly,
some of it won't.

But we wanted to take you through

And the best place to begin

design and it working inside
of Access is building queries.

80
00:04:17.855 --> 00:04:20.586
And so that's what we're going to begin
with is we need to understand queries at

81
00:04:20.586 --> 00:04:21.172
the beginning.

82
00:04:21.172 --> 00:04:25.630
>> All right so like you said, a query,
and let me see if I got this right,

83
00:04:25.630 --> 00:04:28.351
a query is where we're
asking a question of

84
00:04:28.351 --> 00:04:32.674
our tables of our information to
try to retrieve something from it.

85
00:04:32.674 --> 00:04:35.354
>> Right, remember,
we can all ask questions.

86
00:04:35.354 --> 00:04:39.148
But the very fact is in database
terminology a query or a quary,

87
00:04:39.148 --> 00:04:43.302
depending on who you learned it from,
we're asking that question,

88
00:04:43.302 --> 00:04:47.049
but we're trying to retrieve
the answers from our database.

89
00:04:47.049 --> 00:04:51.115
And what is generated as a result
of those queries is what we've

90
00:04:51.115 --> 00:04:53.273
actually termed as a record set.

91
00:04:53.273 --> 00:04:56.612
Now it's gonna look in the end
result like a table, but

92
00:04:56.612 --> 00:04:58.653
it's kind of a temporary table.

93
00:04:58.653 --> 00:05:02.060
We're not really creating another
structure at the end of the query.

94
00:05:02.060 --> 00:05:04.790
But what we're doing here is
we're actually creating what we

95
00:05:04.790 --> 00:05:07.678
believe is a result from all of
those different tables that we've

96
00:05:07.678 --> 00:05:10.531
now have connected together in
the relationships that we have.

97
00:05:10.531 --> 00:05:13.555
And we believe that we can
run a query against them and

98
00:05:13.555 --> 00:05:18.111
retrieve the exact information we are
expecting to see when we run this query.

99
00:05:18.111 --> 00:05:21.809
So that's why it is important that we
understand this idea of the query.

100
00:05:21.809 --> 00:05:25.506
There are multiple types of
queries that are available to us,

101
00:05:25.506 --> 00:05:29.772
especially in Access and in the real
world and working with databases,

102
00:05:29.772 --> 00:05:34.199
we can actually do queries that do more
than just show us the information.

103
00:05:34.199 --> 00:05:37.238
We're gonna start with just

104
00:05:37.238 --> 00:05:40.285
we'll talk about why we actually
wanna do that in a moment.

105
00:05:40.285 --> 00:05:44.483
But I do wanna take the time to at least
show you some of the different types of

106
00:05:44.483 --> 00:05:47.630
queries that you can run in
Access to help us out, okay?

107
00:05:47.630 --> 00:05:50.682
So Vonne, let's go ahead and
take a look at my machine, and

108
00:05:50.682 --> 00:05:52.401
this will get us started, okay?

109
00:05:52.401 --> 00:05:53.483
So here it is.

110
00:05:53.483 --> 00:05:57.035
Here's my Access database that
I have open on dancing dogs.

111
00:05:57.035 --> 00:06:00.740
Here's all of the actual different
tables that I have over here.

112
00:06:00.740 --> 00:06:03.727
And then I've got a couple of queries
down here on the left-hand side.

113
00:06:03.727 --> 00:06:06.111
These were just for
testing and for practice, and

114
00:06:06.111 --> 00:06:09.814
just trying to make sure that everything
was working the way that I want it to.

115
00:06:09.814 --> 00:06:13.656
But up here at the top, just to show
you some of the different ones, but

116
00:06:13.656 --> 00:06:16.928
we're actually gonna take a look
in this group right here.

117
00:06:16.928 --> 00:06:20.155
That is called well queries grouping.

118
00:06:20.155 --> 00:06:24.323
Notice that there's a query wizard and
there's a query design, okay?

119
00:06:24.323 --> 00:06:29.050
Now for us to be able to take a look at
some of the different types of queries

120
00:06:29.050 --> 00:06:33.719
that you and I can create, I'm simply
gonna click on the query design.

121
00:06:33.719 --> 00:06:36.214
And I'm gonna close out
of the show tables for

122
00:06:36.214 --> 00:06:39.900
a moment cuz I want to focus in on
the query types is what I want to do.

123
00:06:39.900 --> 00:06:44.772
So up at the top, notice that
the Contextual Design tab has shown up

124
00:06:44.772 --> 00:06:49.210
underneath the query tools and
now I have these query types.

125
00:06:49.210 --> 00:06:54.157
So in the query types here,
we're really gonna focus on this

126
00:06:54.157 --> 00:06:58.524
first big table or
icons that you see right over here.

127
00:06:58.524 --> 00:07:03.319
These are more advanced types of them too,
but we're really gonna be focusing on this

128
00:07:03.319 --> 00:07:07.463
one for at least this particular show,
which is the select query, okay?

129
00:07:07.463 --> 00:07:10.223
The select query,
when we start describing this,

130
00:07:10.223 --> 00:07:13.495
what we're gonna do is we're
going to go into our database,

131
00:07:13.495 --> 00:07:17.494
whether it's actually a single table or
whether it's multiple tables.

132
00:07:17.494 --> 00:07:20.285
And we're gonna tell it
I need to actually pull

133
00:07:20.285 --> 00:07:25.026

and I need you to display them to me.

134
00:07:25.026 --> 00:07:27.185
And when it displays it to you,

135
00:07:27.185 --> 00:07:32.185
it's actually making a copy of that
information and showing it to you.

136
00:07:32.185 --> 00:07:36.946
Now that copy itself does not turn into
a permanent table even though it actually

137
00:07:36.946 --> 00:07:40.515
does look like a table at the end
in the result when we see it.

138
00:07:40.515 --> 00:07:41.736
>> Could this be similar?

139
00:07:41.736 --> 00:07:44.401
Cuz what I'm thinking
right now again Excel,

140
00:07:44.401 --> 00:07:46.870
I want to filter out certain information.

141
00:07:46.870 --> 00:07:51.033
I mean we could kinda use
that term of show me all of

142
00:07:51.033 --> 00:07:54.296
the products that were sold in Tampa.

143
00:07:54.296 --> 00:07:58.290
>> Right.
>> That's to me in my Excel thinking like

144
00:07:58.290 --> 00:07:59.315
a filter.

145
00:07:59.315 --> 00:08:00.123
Yes.
>> Okay.

146
00:08:00.123 --> 00:08:03.131
>> Yeah,
it's very similar in what we can do there.

147
00:08:03.131 --> 00:08:07.941
And the difference is that we can actually
now do it between multiple tables wherein

148
00:08:07.941 --> 00:08:13.150
the Excel analogy we could do it between
multiple spreadsheets using one query.

149
00:08:13.150 --> 00:08:15.970
Whereas instead inside Excel,
you'd have to actually run it probably

150
00:08:15.970 --> 00:08:19.000
on each spreadsheet to give you
the results that you want to.

151
00:08:19.000 --> 00:08:19.850
And also in Excel,

152
00:08:19.850 --> 00:08:23.260
when you put it someplace it actually
does become another sheet as well.

153
00:08:23.260 --> 00:08:24.990
Where this is just temporary.

154
00:08:24.990 --> 00:08:29.000
It's actually just gonna be stored in
RAM until you actually need it again.

155
00:08:29.000 --> 00:08:32.220
You can save the query, in other words,
tell it hey, I wanna run this again.

156
00:08:32.220 --> 00:08:34.640
But it's not gonna save the results for
you.

157
00:08:34.640 --> 00:08:37.180
Unless you actually do make
it into a table of some sort.

158
00:08:37.180 --> 00:08:40.360

episodes.description: Ronnie and Vonne continue to share some of the issues they discovered in their database from running queries. In this episode, they reveal issues with the relationships between tables and demonstrate how to fix them.

episodes.description: In the final episode of the query mini-series, Vonne and Ronnie discuss some of the final issues they discovered in their database design.  They reestablish some more table relationships and add fields to correct some logic issues with the data.

00:21:35.980 --> 00:21:39.320
And now we can move on and
create some other things.

375
00:21:39.320 --> 00:21:42.840
>> Wow, I feel we've been up and
down and all around.

376
00:21:42.840 --> 00:21:45.600
And gone through all of our different
things that we were going through,

377
00:21:45.600 --> 00:21:46.540
our mini series of.

378
00:21:46.540 --> 00:21:47.450
>> Yep.
>> Queries.

379
00:21:47.450 --> 00:21:48.380
Our query mini series.

380
00:21:48.380 --> 00:21:52.655
And now it's coming to a close, and I feel
like I need to shed a little tear because.

381
00:21:52.655 --> 00:21:54.400
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now we're done with queries.

382
00:21:54.400 --> 00:21:57.760
But the exciting thing is
that we're gonna come back.

383
00:21:57.760 --> 00:21:59.595
>> Right.
>> With some more mini series.

384
00:21:59.595 --> 00:22:01.740
[LAUGH] Or at least some episodes, right?

385
00:22:01.740 --> 00:22:02.240
>> Right.

386
00:22:02.240 --> 00:22:07.529
>> And going on to moving on to our new
things in our new things in our access,

387
00:22:07.529 --> 00:22:10.650
In the world of access, and
seriously I want to start singing and

388
00:22:10.650 --> 00:22:13.365
making closing music and everything for us
>> Woah

389
00:22:13.365 --> 00:22:16.011
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, we'll go ahead and

390
00:22:16.011 --> 00:22:17.582
not do that [LAUGH].

391
00:22:17.582 --> 00:22:21.833
Well we have wrapped up so we're going to
go ahead and sign off for Office Pro TV,

392
00:22:21.833 --> 00:22:24.340
I've been your host Yvonne Smith
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong

393
00:22:24.340 --> 00:22:25.819
>> And we'll see you soon.

394
00:22:25.819 --> 00:22:30.241
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Ronnie discuss the importance of forms in Access. They show how to create a form using the form button and introduce the concept of a subform. They end the episode with a brief introduction to the form wizard.
episodes.title: Creating Basic Forms
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:09.672
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.280 --> 00:00:16.267
Hello, everyone and welcome back to
another exciting episode of OfficeProTV.

3
00:00:16.267 --> 00:00:17.563
I'm your host, Vonne Smith.

4
00:00:17.563 --> 00:00:21.925
And today we're continuing on with
our Access 2016 Essential show.

5
00:00:21.925 --> 00:00:24.965
In this episode,
we're gonna be talking all about forms.

6
00:00:24.965 --> 00:00:26.845
And here to help us is Mr Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:26.845 --> 00:00:28.024
Hello, how are you?

8
00:00:28.024 --> 00:00:29.080
>> I am doing fine, Vonne.

9
00:00:29.080 --> 00:00:33.765
Thank you again for the invitation
back to OfficePro Studio this year.

10
00:00:33.765 --> 00:00:37.500
As we continue on taking a look
of course at Access 2016,

11
00:00:37.500 --> 00:00:41.064
we are now talking about
of course creating forms.

12
00:00:41.064 --> 00:00:44.000
Now Vonee, we've already created tables,

13
00:00:44.000 --> 00:00:48.720
we've done through a little bit of
design basics, we've created queries.

14
00:00:48.720 --> 00:00:50.760
We will actually have
to ask that question,

15
00:00:50.760 --> 00:00:53.770
why in the world do we
need to create forms?

16
00:00:53.770 --> 00:00:58.202
So it's actually a good question for
us to spend a little bit of time on.

17
00:00:58.202 --> 00:01:02.676
So Vonne, if you were to take
a guess at the idea here of trying.

18
00:01:02.676 --> 00:01:06.458
Now that you understand that we've gotten
everything done, we've done our testing,

19
00:01:06.458 --> 00:01:08.090
everything is working.

20
00:01:08.090 --> 00:01:09.686
What is a form about in the database?

21
00:01:09.686 --> 00:01:11.243
What do you think the answer would be?

22
00:01:11.243 --> 00:01:13.165
>> Well, normally when you have forms,

23
00:01:13.165 --> 00:01:16.350
there's only certain things
that you can do in the forms.

24
00:01:16.350 --> 00:01:20.150
Like if it asks you to enter your name,
you can type a name.

25
00:01:20.150 --> 00:01:23.400
Or, there's certain ones where
there's like a dropdown menu.

26
00:01:23.400 --> 00:01:25.890
So where it's controlling
like what state are you in?

27
00:01:25.890 --> 00:01:30.601
Well, if these are your only choices,
so you can't just willy-nilly add in any

28
00:01:30.601 --> 00:01:34.845
information that you want, so
you can kinda control things with forms.

29
00:01:34.845 --> 00:01:39.020
So, I'm assuming that's where you can
control how stuff is entered into your

30
00:01:39.020 --> 00:01:42.767
database and we've kind of already
hinted on that in our vocabulary.

31
00:01:42.767 --> 00:01:45.188
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, I've been paying attention, Ronnie.

32
00:01:45.188 --> 00:01:47.634
I was like, I know that definition so.

33
00:01:47.634 --> 00:01:48.587
[LAUGH]
>> All right,

34
00:01:48.587 --> 00:01:50.320
yeah, Vonne and you're right.

35
00:01:50.320 --> 00:01:52.610
The very fact is we need
some type of control.

36
00:01:52.610 --> 00:01:55.720
Let's take a look at my machine and
let's talk about what we mean here

37
00:01:55.720 --> 00:01:59.030
if the language that we've been
using is a little bit confusing.

38
00:01:59.030 --> 00:02:01.616
So remember, we already created tables and
queries, and

39
00:02:01.616 --> 00:02:04.161
we're about to work in this
grouping here called forms.

40
00:02:04.161 --> 00:02:09.100
But I launched up this customer's
table just a few seconds ago, okay.

41
00:02:09.100 --> 00:02:13.510
If we want to start doing some
data entry right now, okay, well,

42
00:02:13.510 --> 00:02:16.180
how do I do this in this table, Vonne?

43
00:02:16.180 --> 00:02:17.670
Okay, well, it's simple.

44
00:02:17.670 --> 00:02:22.110
Down here at the bottom left-hand corner
just about, notice that I have this

45
00:02:22.110 --> 00:02:26.710
ability to be able to move through records
by using these navigation tools down here.

46
00:02:26.710 --> 00:02:30.320
So I have where I can go to the next
record of course using this.

47
00:02:30.320 --> 00:02:32.240
I can of course go to the last record.

48
00:02:32.240 --> 00:02:37.294
I can continue to navigate around, but it
gives me this button right here too, okay.

49
00:02:37.294 --> 00:02:39.980
New blank record, okay?

50
00:02:39.980 --> 00:02:42.610
Well that new blank record,
I don't have to even use that.

51
00:02:42.610 --> 00:02:47.130
If I want to, I can just use the scroll
bar over on the right-hand side,

52
00:02:47.130 --> 00:02:50.840
scroll down, oops,
scroll way down before I wanted to, okay?

53
00:02:50.840 --> 00:02:54.020
Now, I just click on this next field here,
and

54
00:02:54.020 --> 00:02:57.770
I simply start typing in
the information that I want.

55
00:02:57.770 --> 00:03:01.100
Now Vonne,
you can see I already did that one time

56
00:03:01.100 --> 00:03:05.580
earlier to trying make our data work
the way that I wanted to for number 25.

57
00:03:05.580 --> 00:03:09.220
Notice I didn't have to enter
in everything in there, okay?

58
00:03:09.220 --> 00:03:12.620
I skip Loyalty IDs,
Store Number, Address, and

59
00:03:12.620 --> 00:03:17.390
everything because I needed a way to
be able to account for cash customers,

60
00:03:17.390 --> 00:03:20.310
by just name the cash customer
that's all I ended up doing, okay.

61
00:03:20.310 --> 00:03:24.740
But Vonne,
in that particular instance, okay,

62
00:03:24.740 --> 00:03:29.345
that was just because I wanted to work and
I wanted to be able to account for that.

63
00:03:29.345 --> 00:03:33.140
There's a lot of times when we
are not the only ones thats gonna

64
00:03:33.140 --> 00:03:37.250
be doing the data entry, and
we don't want a record like that, okay.

65
00:03:37.250 --> 00:03:42.290
Vonne, with this particular record here,
on cash customers, do I know, perhaps,

66
00:03:42.290 --> 00:03:45.050
what particular store they might
of even actually gone into?

67
00:03:45.050 --> 00:03:48.914
>> No, I mean, you don't have any
of the information that you need or

68
00:03:48.914 --> 00:03:53.477
that you might need if this, I know why
we did this for a very specific purpose.

69
00:03:53.477 --> 00:03:58.259
And it's not fine to not have like
the information, there's just this

70
00:03:58.259 --> 00:04:03.132
somebody else, you need to have
the loyalty number and the customer ID.

71
00:04:03.132 --> 00:04:03.790
>> Yeah.
>> And,

72
00:04:03.790 --> 00:04:06.114
since the customer ID is the primary,
right,

73
00:04:06.114 --> 00:04:09.940
you don't wanna duplicate record and
all those different types of things.

74
00:04:09.940 --> 00:04:14.950
So this would be something if
it was like a regular customer

75
00:04:14.950 --> 00:04:16.730
this would be missing information.

76
00:04:16.730 --> 00:04:18.644
>> Right.
>> And it would like kind of,

77
00:04:18.644 --> 00:04:21.172
I don't know if corrupt is too strong of

78
00:04:21.172 --> 00:04:23.857
a word but kind of-
>> It leaves gaps in the information that

79
00:04:23.857 --> 00:04:24.850
we're trying to pull.

80
00:04:24.850 --> 00:04:27.920
>> Yeah, yeah,
cuz corrupt sounds so broken,

81
00:04:27.920 --> 00:04:31.310
but it could lead to some
really broken results if you're

82
00:04:31.310 --> 00:04:34.120
relying on things a store number
that the customer has brought.

83
00:04:34.120 --> 00:04:35.310
>> Yeah, and that's true.

84
00:04:35.310 --> 00:04:39.229
So, the reason why I wanted to point
this out, right, is that it gives us

85
00:04:39.229 --> 00:04:43.489
this ability to actually enter in the data
that we want, I know at the minimum.

86
00:04:43.489 --> 00:04:44.600
Vonne's right.

87
00:04:44.600 --> 00:04:46.690
I need to enter in the customer ID,

88
00:04:46.690 --> 00:04:49.150
but I didn't really need to
enter anything else in here.

89
00:04:49.150 --> 00:04:51.360
It would probably just let me
enter in a customer ID and

90
00:04:51.360 --> 00:04:53.050
I could have gone on with the next record.

91
00:04:53.050 --> 00:04:55.308
I would have had blank everything else.

92
00:04:55.308 --> 00:04:57.960
Well, Vonne, then we go and
query this information and

93
00:04:57.960 --> 00:05:01.530
you see customer number 25, but
you don't know what it means.

94
00:05:01.530 --> 00:05:03.320
It doesn't mean anything.

95
00:05:03.320 --> 00:05:07.320
So a form though can give us this ability

96
00:05:07.320 --> 00:05:11.430
to help us out a little bit more
where what we can do is we can say,

97
00:05:11.430 --> 00:05:14.610
here's the information you
must enter in when we want to.

98
00:05:14.610 --> 00:05:16.950
So it can provide a measure
of control as well.

99
00:05:16.950 --> 00:05:18.387
>> It's like those required fields.

100
00:05:18.387 --> 00:05:21.030
I mean,
we probably fill out forms all day long.

101
00:05:21.030 --> 00:05:25.853
Well, you fill out a form to get to
actually access this Access show,

102
00:05:25.853 --> 00:05:29.856
cuz you had to become a member
of OfficeProTV or ITProTV.

103
00:05:29.856 --> 00:05:33.854
And so that's were it had just
like you have to insert your name,

104
00:05:33.854 --> 00:05:37.854
you have to insert your date of birth,
or whatever that record or

105
00:05:37.854 --> 00:05:42.890
information that we need so we have
form controls that we can put on there.

106
00:05:42.890 --> 00:05:47.211
>> And form controls will come along for
us at least at a later day and

107
00:05:47.211 --> 00:05:50.583
might be a series I will
do on the Access Advanced.

108
00:05:50.583 --> 00:05:54.030
But at this point, you gotta understand
that forms really do help us.

109
00:05:54.030 --> 00:05:55.573
They also can help us by doing this.

110
00:05:55.573 --> 00:06:01.066
Vonne, let's say that this is not you and
me doing the damage but

111
00:06:01.066 --> 00:06:05.210
we handed it off to
someone else to do this.

112
00:06:05.210 --> 00:06:07.270
And we said, all right,
here's all you have to do.

113
00:06:07.270 --> 00:06:10.088
Copy what's on these paper forms and
put it in there.

114
00:06:10.088 --> 00:06:12.933
When they start to copy information, and

115
00:06:12.933 --> 00:06:15.870
then lets say they look
at this right here.

116
00:06:15.870 --> 00:06:18.680
Now Vonne,
you're a better speller than I am, okay?

117
00:06:18.680 --> 00:06:21.580
Windermere, that looks right to me.

118
00:06:21.580 --> 00:06:24.180
But let's say that the person
that did that entry said,

119
00:06:24.180 --> 00:06:25.670
that's not how you spell Windermere.

120
00:06:25.670 --> 00:06:28.650
And they come in here and
they start changing that.

121
00:06:28.650 --> 00:06:32.530
Or, they start looking and go wait,
that's not how you spell John.

122
00:06:32.530 --> 00:06:34.980
It should be spelled
some other different way.

123
00:06:34.980 --> 00:06:39.635
Well, this actually allows someone that
doesn't really have any information

124
00:06:39.635 --> 00:06:42.142
about what was actually entered in there.

125
00:06:42.142 --> 00:06:47.305
And why it was entered in the way that
they did to start inadvertently updating,

126
00:06:47.305 --> 00:06:52.120
or what we call unauthorized updating
of the records as well, okay?

127
00:06:52.120 --> 00:06:56.202
Well that can be just as damaging because
the people that probably entered it

128
00:06:56.202 --> 00:06:59.404
in in the first place and
knew exactly what they were doing.

129
00:06:59.404 --> 00:07:02.905
You've gotta understand that maybe
Windermere is not the way that that person

130
00:07:02.905 --> 00:07:05.690
would have spelled it, but
it is the correct spelling.

131
00:07:05.690 --> 00:07:09.760
Whatever it is, we don't want anybody
else inadvertently doing this.

132
00:07:09.760 --> 00:07:12.040
And our eyes automatically do this,
right Vonne?

133
00:07:12.040 --> 00:07:16.700
We look at all of these different fields
in here, and all of a sudden I go, that

134
00:07:16.700 --> 00:07:20.800
can't be the proper spelling and for some
reason it bugs me enough I feel like what?

135
00:07:20.800 --> 00:07:23.060
I've got to go in and
I've got to change that.

136
00:07:23.060 --> 00:07:24.950
Well, that's not something
I really want to happen,

137
00:07:24.950 --> 00:07:29.160
especially by someone that doesn't
know what the data is, okay.

138
00:07:29.160 --> 00:07:32.644
So this is something that we really
want to make sure that we understand and

139
00:07:32.644 --> 00:07:35.300
forms can help us to control
stuff like that as well.

140
00:07:35.300 --> 00:07:38.000
>> Yeah, cuz I know that
talking to you about databases

141
00:07:38.000 --> 00:07:40.870
throughout all these years and
everything like that.

142
00:07:40.870 --> 00:07:47.402
That you always say, don't let your
users manipulate the tables themselves.

143
00:07:47.402 --> 00:07:50.460
It's like the sacred ground or
something like that.

144
00:07:50.460 --> 00:07:54.733
You don't want people going
directly to the source data.

145
00:07:54.733 --> 00:07:55.257
>> Right.

146
00:07:55.257 --> 00:08:00.315
>> You wanna protect that source data,
and this is exactly where forms comes

147
00:08:00.315 --> 00:08:05.690
into play Is don't have them interact
with your data with the tables.

148
00:08:05.690 --> 00:08:10.360
They interact with the forms cuz then
you control what they can and cannot do.

149
00:08:10.360 --> 00:08:12.920
>> Right, and
it really does make a difference here.

150
00:08:12.920 --> 00:08:17.270
The very fact that we can do that
inadvertent updating means also somebody

151
00:08:17.270 --> 00:08:21.620
could possibly come in and
select a record right here.

152
00:08:21.620 --> 00:08:22.581
Right-click on it.

153
00:08:22.581 --> 00:08:25.040
And notice this, Vonne, okay?

154
00:08:25.040 --> 00:08:28.930
That gives them access to be able
to delete a record if they want to.

155
00:08:28.930 --> 00:08:31.440
Let's say that just think
they're only deleting stuff that

156
00:08:31.440 --> 00:08:35.020
they entered in because they thought
that they entered in incorrectly.

157
00:08:35.020 --> 00:08:36.350
Well, do they know that?

158
00:08:36.350 --> 00:08:39.530
Do they absolutely know how many
records that they entered in?

159
00:08:39.530 --> 00:08:42.003
Are they just saying,
I think I only entered in five or six?

160
00:08:42.003 --> 00:08:44.349
And all of sudden they select instead,

161
00:08:44.349 --> 00:08:48.940
let's say, all of a sudden they
select all these along with it.

162
00:08:48.940 --> 00:08:51.603
So this is something
that we want to prevent.

163
00:08:51.603 --> 00:08:56.193
We don't really want anybody messing
around the data that already exists in our

164
00:08:56.193 --> 00:08:56.752
tables.

165
00:08:56.752 --> 00:08:58.780
And along with this, right?

166
00:08:58.780 --> 00:09:02.820
If they have access to all this, well,
they can also start manipulating and

167
00:09:02.820 --> 00:09:05.610
changing all the other data here as well.

168
00:09:05.610 --> 00:09:10.020
But any of this unauthorized modification
or deletion is really a bad thing.

169
00:09:10.020 --> 00:09:11.310
Forms can help us control that, too.

170
00:09:11.310 --> 00:09:13.780
>> And
that's where I get into organization.

171
00:09:13.780 --> 00:09:15.790
You might like,
I've never even looked at the tables,

172
00:09:15.790 --> 00:09:16.973
I've never even seen these tables.

173
00:09:16.973 --> 00:09:20.030
Which, if you're watching these episodes,
is like I don't see any of that.

174
00:09:20.030 --> 00:09:23.830
I mean,
depending on what level of database you

175
00:09:23.830 --> 00:09:27.180
have in within your organization, you
might have like a database administrator,

176
00:09:27.180 --> 00:09:29.650
that they're the only ones
that has access to the tables.

177
00:09:29.650 --> 00:09:30.850
>> Right.
>> Cuz you,

178
00:09:30.850 --> 00:09:34.080
I know we're getting kind of beyond
this scope of a basic class right now.

179
00:09:34.080 --> 00:09:35.440
>> Right.
>> But you can lock things down and

180
00:09:35.440 --> 00:09:36.440
put security on it.

181
00:09:36.440 --> 00:09:38.550
>> And so on and so
forth when you have multiple users.

182
00:09:38.550 --> 00:09:42.740
So this is where you might, okay,
well I've seen these forms.

183
00:09:42.740 --> 00:09:45.290
And you might not even be able
to manipulate the forms, but

184
00:09:45.290 --> 00:09:47.670
at least you have an idea now why.

185
00:09:47.670 --> 00:09:49.890
>> Right.
>> The forms exist in the first place.

186
00:09:49.890 --> 00:09:52.920
>> And now, Vonne, you might be
wondering why do I keep harping on this?

187
00:09:52.920 --> 00:09:54.780
Because it's really that important.

188
00:09:54.780 --> 00:09:59.830
Now, Vonne, what if it's not a deletion or
a modification mistake that somebody has,

189
00:09:59.830 --> 00:10:03.900
but in this sense that without the forms,
they

190
00:10:03.900 --> 00:10:08.220
also end up having access to data that
they don't need to have access to, right?

191
00:10:08.220 --> 00:10:10.878
So someone could be doing data entry and
they come here and

192
00:10:10.878 --> 00:10:15.630
go, I wonder if I could just take
a look at the sales stuff, okay?

193
00:10:15.630 --> 00:10:18.960
And this is also problematic as well.

194
00:10:18.960 --> 00:10:23.823
The very fact that we essentially end up
granting somebody unauthorized access in

195
00:10:23.823 --> 00:10:28.756
these tables, they may not do anything to
modify or update or delete anything, but

196
00:10:28.756 --> 00:10:34.170
just having access or unauthorized access
to this data may not be what they want to.

197
00:10:34.170 --> 00:10:36.610
Or what if or one, and
this would be a bad idea.

198
00:10:36.610 --> 00:10:40.660
But what if we actually
kept like basic daily or

199
00:10:40.660 --> 00:10:44.810
hourly salary information in
our employees table here, okay?

200
00:10:44.810 --> 00:10:46.500
And they noticed that
their name was in it.

201
00:10:46.500 --> 00:10:49.280
And they noticed that Ronnie or
Vonne's name was in it.

202
00:10:49.280 --> 00:10:50.860

00:19:12.665 --> 00:19:16.642
where you just kinda took that
loyalty ID- and moved it down, well,

363
00:19:16.642 --> 00:19:20.162
the field it's associated with
was way over off to the side.

364
00:19:20.162 --> 00:19:27.095
So you gotta be a little careful
about where you're going in this.

365
00:19:27.095 --> 00:19:27.755
>> You really do.

366
00:19:27.755 --> 00:19:32.552
So that blank thing sounds
wonderful until you do that, right?

367
00:19:32.552 --> 00:19:35.780
Now and this actually does lead us, let me
go ahead and finish the rest of this so

368
00:19:35.780 --> 00:19:36.790
that you can see it.

369
00:19:36.790 --> 00:19:40.224
I'm just gonna double click and have it
placed where it should be, there we go.

370
00:19:40.224 --> 00:19:43.301
Okay, and that should actually put
everything the way they want to.

371
00:19:43.301 --> 00:19:46.951
From this point, you can now add
in modifications and formatting,

372
00:19:46.951 --> 00:19:48.688
whatever else needs to be done.

373
00:19:48.688 --> 00:19:52.483
But there is one more thing I wanna show
you about this field list though, okay?

374
00:19:52.483 --> 00:19:54.928
One of the things that really irked me,
Vonne,

375
00:19:54.928 --> 00:19:58.845
at the very beginning when I started
learning about access is that field list

376
00:19:58.845 --> 00:20:01.100
used to not be just set here, okay?

377
00:20:01.100 --> 00:20:04.500
When you first started, it would appear
on the screen like a floating window.

378
00:20:04.500 --> 00:20:08.040
And if you were like me, you're going
okay, I wanna look at that next.

379
00:20:08.040 --> 00:20:10.000
Let me just take a look
at the whole thing.

380
00:20:10.000 --> 00:20:12.669
You went and you clicked in here,
and the field list disappeared.

381
00:20:12.669 --> 00:20:14.574
So I know you remember that, Vonne.

382
00:20:14.574 --> 00:20:18.418
I mean, the field list would disappear,
and you're looking like okay,

383
00:20:18.418 --> 00:20:19.663
the field list is gone.

384
00:20:19.663 --> 00:20:21.543
How do I get that back?

385
00:20:21.543 --> 00:20:23.170
>> Yeah, what am I supposed to do now?

386
00:20:23.170 --> 00:20:24.740
>> What am I supposed to do now?

387
00:20:24.740 --> 00:20:28.290
And that was really frustrating, because
everything was underneath those menus.

388
00:20:28.290 --> 00:20:32.500
Well, up here in the Tools section,
or the Tools grouping, okay,

389
00:20:32.500 --> 00:20:37.970
all I have to do is select Add Existing
Fields, okay, and that's what will be.

390
00:20:37.970 --> 00:20:41.180
And that will go ahead and
put the field list back over here

391
00:20:41.180 --> 00:20:45.200
on the right hand side for
you to be able to do this.

392
00:20:45.200 --> 00:20:49.040
So it does give us some
measure of freedom.

393
00:20:49.040 --> 00:20:53.147
But notice how it's very controlled in
what it sets in that grouping as what we

394
00:20:53.147 --> 00:20:53.725
see here.

395
00:20:53.725 --> 00:20:57.704
>> And I don't know if this is
the proper place to say this, but

396
00:20:57.704 --> 00:21:01.340
I feel like this could be
a little dangerous too.

397
00:21:01.340 --> 00:21:05.850
If you're just willy nilly grabbing
a field from one table and

398
00:21:05.850 --> 00:21:09.200
then putting another one from
another table and it's all together.

399
00:21:09.200 --> 00:21:14.625
Well, if we're trying to maintain data
integrity, for lack of a better term,

400
00:21:14.625 --> 00:21:19.790
you're just gonna fill in this one place,
but not the rest of the record.

401
00:21:19.790 --> 00:21:23.595
So this is where we can kinda
get ourselves in trouble, maybe?

402
00:21:23.595 --> 00:21:27.809
>> I think it's possible if we hadn't
turned on referential integrity, okay?

403
00:21:27.809 --> 00:21:31.714
So because we actually did enable
referential integrity between

404
00:21:31.714 --> 00:21:34.840
those tables,
we shouldn't be able to do that.

405
00:21:34.840 --> 00:21:37.700
In other words, if we try and
update that one table, and it may

406
00:21:37.700 --> 00:21:41.345
actually have to update another record
in the other table, it should update.

407
00:21:41.345 --> 00:21:45.388
The same thing, if I delete something out
of this one table, and it may influence

408
00:21:45.388 --> 00:21:49.430
the other one on the other table,
it should also delete that out as well.

409
00:21:49.430 --> 00:21:52.220
So that referential integrity
is very important at this point.

410
00:21:52.220 --> 00:21:55.700
>> Well, I guess right here, on the one
that we see right here on the screen,

411
00:21:55.700 --> 00:21:58.134
what if I did not put city,
phone, email, state?

412
00:21:58.134 --> 00:22:01.560
I just left those off and just put
first name, last name, and address.

413
00:22:01.560 --> 00:22:02.940
Well, if somebody filled this out,

414
00:22:02.940 --> 00:22:07.860
then the record in the table
would be incomplete.

415
00:22:07.860 --> 00:22:08.400
>> Correct.

416
00:22:08.400 --> 00:22:11.555
>> So that's where-
>> We lose gaps.

417
00:22:11.555 --> 00:22:14.377
>> Okay, and you don't-
>> You don't wanna do that.

418
00:22:14.377 --> 00:22:18.278
>> Yeah, I guess that's where I was kinda
going with that question in the sense.

419
00:22:18.278 --> 00:22:22.674
And so if [CROSSTALK]
>> Yeah, if you forget that stop,

420
00:22:22.674 --> 00:22:26.990
then it won't be there for
somebody to enter the data entry in.

421
00:22:26.990 --> 00:22:30.870
So building a form, this is why I
recommend, Vonne, that if we do this for

422
00:22:30.870 --> 00:22:35.340
somebody else, it's easier if we
actually say, here's what I'm gonna do,

423
00:22:35.340 --> 00:22:38.370
I'm gonna create a select query, okay?

424
00:22:38.370 --> 00:22:42.890
And then this is when I know that Bob
is going to have to enter the data in,

425
00:22:42.890 --> 00:22:44.280
and we'll tell him.

426
00:22:44.280 --> 00:22:48.205
Make sure you do not leave the field blank
and later on decide with the advance

427
00:22:48.205 --> 00:22:51.658
access show actually see where we say,
you can't leave it blank.

428
00:22:51.658 --> 00:22:55.020
It has to have something in there
to make sure it goes on, and

429
00:22:55.020 --> 00:22:59.910
we can even control the way how the actual
letters even appear, if we want to.

430
00:22:59.910 --> 00:23:02.630
So it's amazing that the controls
that you really do have,

431
00:23:02.630 --> 00:23:05.400
but this is a big part of it, right?

432
00:23:05.400 --> 00:23:09.361
The very fact that we can at least get
the data in there, another fast and

433
00:23:09.361 --> 00:23:13.141
furious method, it gives you a little
bit more control in this way.

434
00:23:13.141 --> 00:23:15.648
Unlike the way that we did
when we hit the form button,

435
00:23:15.648 --> 00:23:17.930
where it just pulled in that table.

436
00:23:17.930 --> 00:23:20.950
But this one does give you
the ability to do both.

437
00:23:20.950 --> 00:23:24.248
Actually, I'm lying to you,
this one only gives you the ability to do,

438
00:23:24.248 --> 00:23:26.356
I was looking over here
on the right hand side,

439
00:23:26.356 --> 00:23:29.250
gives you the ability to actually
only look in the tables here.

440
00:23:29.250 --> 00:23:30.282
I wanna share with you,

441
00:23:30.282 --> 00:23:33.081
this one actually gave me the ability
to look at queries as well.

442
00:23:33.081 --> 00:23:37.056
But both the regular form button,
as well as the actual blank form,

443
00:23:37.056 --> 00:23:40.488
which is what this one is,
it will not allow you to do that.

444
00:23:40.488 --> 00:23:45.042
You're simply gonna have to select from
tables, so that's why we also then,

445
00:23:45.042 --> 00:23:47.531
if we know that that is what's happening.

446
00:23:47.531 --> 00:23:49.452
And this is what's happening,
Vonne, is that,

447
00:23:49.452 --> 00:23:52.401
let's say that we've gone through now and
we've taken a look at the forms.

448
00:23:52.401 --> 00:23:56.047
And got, it'll work, but
it's not what I really want.

449
00:23:56.047 --> 00:23:58.823
We go through the wizard and
say, it's basic.

450
00:23:58.823 --> 00:24:02.785
It shows me, and I think I could
take that and massage it around and

451
00:24:02.785 --> 00:24:03.876
do what I want to.

452
00:24:03.876 --> 00:24:06.535
I'd have to get rid of a lot of stuff
to make it work, we can do that.

453
00:24:06.535 --> 00:24:09.846
And this one,
it doesn't really do what I wanna do, but

454
00:24:09.846 --> 00:24:12.457
I could work with it,
if I needed to, okay?

455
00:24:12.457 --> 00:24:16.184
Well, if all that is not what
you're really looking for,

456
00:24:16.184 --> 00:24:20.920
that means you have to manually create
your own custom form at that point.

457
00:24:20.920 --> 00:24:23.683
And that's what we still
need to actually do.

458
00:24:23.683 --> 00:24:27.659
So Vonne, as we actually take a look at
this, it means that we really have to do

459
00:24:27.659 --> 00:24:31.416
that, but I don't think I can do that
in three minutes that we have left.

460
00:24:31.416 --> 00:24:32.440
>> [LAUGH]
>> So Vonne,

461
00:24:32.440 --> 00:24:34.707
it looks like we're gonna have to
actually do a part three here.

462
00:24:34.707 --> 00:24:36.966
>> There's that fine acting
coming through again.

463
00:24:36.966 --> 00:24:40.391
>> [LAUGH]
>> He'll leave us guessing of what's gonna

464
00:24:40.391 --> 00:24:41.239
come up next.

465
00:24:41.239 --> 00:24:43.328
Well, you kinda already told us that,
[LAUGH].

466
00:24:43.328 --> 00:24:44.630
We're gonna build a custom form.

467
00:24:44.630 --> 00:24:48.732
[LAUGH] And I'm assuming that we're gonna
do some of those things that we saw up in

468
00:24:48.732 --> 00:24:51.809
the ribbon up there with the drop
downs and the check boxes.

469
00:24:51.809 --> 00:24:54.979
And this is something that I
do know a decent amount about.

470
00:24:54.979 --> 00:24:55.839
>> Good, excellent.

471
00:24:55.839 --> 00:24:58.207
>> So
maybe I can help bring in some insight.

472
00:24:58.207 --> 00:24:59.958
>> That's right.
>> Besides just asking you question after

473
00:24:59.958 --> 00:25:00.843
question after question.

474
00:25:00.843 --> 00:25:04.547
[LAUGH] Well, let's go ahead and
wrap this episode up.

475
00:25:04.547 --> 00:25:07.403
So we're gonna go ahead and
sign off for OfficeProTV.

476
00:25:07.403 --> 00:25:08.796
I've been your host, Vonne Smith.

477
00:25:08.796 --> 00:25:09.772
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

478
00:25:09.772 --> 00:25:11.037
>> And we'll see you soon.

479
00:25:11.037 --> 00:25:15.254

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Ronnie create a form in design view. They demonstrate how to add label controls and how to manipulate their placement in the form.
episodes.title: Creating Basic Forms Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

[MUSIC]

2

Hello, everyone and

4

Taking a look at forms as Vonne

It's the afternoon right now,

So yeah, maybe I'm the one who's acting

>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, I think so.

>> I'm awake.
>> [LAUGH]

00:01:04.350 --> 00:01:07.195

>> Exactly.
>> As we continue

25
00:01:08.116 --> 00:01:10.649
on through taking a look at,
of course, creating a basic form.

00:01:10.649 --> 00:01:14.509
Now Von, we've already done taking

27
00:01:14.509 --> 00:01:16.390
There are still a few.

28
00:01:16.390 --> 00:01:18.390
I'm not gonna be able to say it.

29
00:01:18.390 --> 00:01:19.866
There's still a few tools.

30
00:01:19.866 --> 00:01:22.100
>> [LAUGH]
>> See, I can't say it.

31
00:01:22.100 --> 00:01:23.540
>> We can do it.
>> Tools out there

00:01:23.540 --> 00:01:25.760
that we need to take a look at as well,

00:01:25.760 --> 00:01:29.010
and then we wanna create a basic
>> Form,

using the Form Design View which is gonna
give us the most control that we need,

35
00:01:32.130 --> 00:01:35.540
and actually fit our needs better,
more than anything else, okay?

36
00:01:35.540 --> 00:01:38.720
So, let's go ahead and
take a look at this as well, okay?

37
00:01:38.720 --> 00:01:42.160
So, last couple of things,
I'm just gonna point this things out for

38
00:01:42.160 --> 00:01:43.720
us a little bit more.

39
00:01:43.720 --> 00:01:47.130
As we've been working in the forms
grouping a little bit, right?

40
00:01:47.130 --> 00:01:51.000
We've gone through and we've created
a form using the form button and

41
00:01:51.000 --> 00:01:53.480
of course the blank form,
which we showed you.

42
00:01:53.480 --> 00:01:56.020
The form wizard we went
all the way through.

43
00:01:56.020 --> 00:01:57.850
We showed you the blank form.

44
00:01:57.850 --> 00:01:59.520
And now there's two more.

45
00:01:59.520 --> 00:02:05.550
Now, these are really for more advanced
types of things that may end up happening.

46
00:02:05.550 --> 00:02:09.010
But notice when it says create
a form that allows people to browse

47
00:02:09.010 --> 00:02:11.380
to different forms or reports.

48
00:02:11.380 --> 00:02:13.400
That's a little bit more unusual.

49
00:02:13.400 --> 00:02:18.510
And what this is saying is that we can
actually create this to give us navigation

50
00:02:18.510 --> 00:02:19.570
differently here.

51
00:02:19.570 --> 00:02:23.050
>> Is this almost like it was like
a DVD menu or something, I'm thinking-

52
00:02:23.050 --> 00:02:23.810
>> Just about yes.

53
00:02:23.810 --> 00:02:28.190
>> Yeah, or like this is like our
main menu because we might have,

54
00:02:28.190 --> 00:02:33.360
let's see we might have 15 forms or
something and three of them are for

55
00:02:33.360 --> 00:02:39.070
employee records and so it is a table
of contents, or it's a form for a form.

56
00:02:39.070 --> 00:02:42.880
>> It's unusual but
this is what, in the olden days.

57
00:02:42.880 --> 00:02:44.830
I'm gonna use the term that
we all use around here.

58
00:02:44.830 --> 00:02:47.066
Which we don't know what it means,
but we do it, back in the day.

59
00:02:47.066 --> 00:02:49.910
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, we all do it.

60
00:02:49.910 --> 00:02:53.195
Back in the day, we used to call
this something like the switchboard.

61
00:02:53.195 --> 00:02:54.066
Now, Vonne,

62
00:02:54.066 --> 00:02:59.600
you remember when we talked about the idea
of a switch board as a switchboard back.

63
00:02:59.600 --> 00:03:03.270
And for those that don't remember that
spine, when you have multiple forms and

64
00:03:03.270 --> 00:03:08.130
you want to lock down those forms, or you
want to actually kind of categorize them,

65
00:03:08.130 --> 00:03:09.740
what you do is you create a switchboard.

66
00:03:09.740 --> 00:03:12.360
And this is the same thing
in terms of navigation.

67
00:03:12.360 --> 00:03:16.800
It allows us to say you wanna go here to
do data entry, then you actually have

68
00:03:16.800 --> 00:03:19.430
three or four forms behind there
that you can do the data entry in.

69
00:03:19.430 --> 00:03:23.330
You want to go and do a query, you instead
can go to these areas and do a query.

70
00:03:23.330 --> 00:03:25.910
And so
this allows you to kind of grove them and

71
00:03:25.910 --> 00:03:28.630
allows you to navigate through them
the way that you want to as well.

72
00:03:28.630 --> 00:03:31.030
>> And
when you're saying locking them down,

73
00:03:31.030 --> 00:03:33.950
in a sense they wouldn't like see them.

74
00:03:33.950 --> 00:03:36.420
>> Right.
>> Over on the left hand main navigation,

75
00:03:36.420 --> 00:03:40.840
where we see tables and queries,
but they see one navigation form.

76
00:03:40.840 --> 00:03:41.560
>> Right.
>> You click it, and

77
00:03:41.560 --> 00:03:44.640
then it gives you all
the options of where you can go.

78
00:03:44.640 --> 00:03:45.730
>> Right, yeah.

79
00:03:45.730 --> 00:03:49.700
Again, you might see buttons, or
you might see tabs across the top

80
00:03:49.700 --> 00:03:52.930
that allow you to pick this one, but
you don't choose to go that one.

81
00:03:52.930 --> 00:03:54.880
Whatever it might be, you have that.

82
00:03:54.880 --> 00:03:57.850
There's also some other forms here, too.

83
00:03:57.850 --> 00:04:00.950
Multiple Items creates a form that
shows multiple records at one time.

84
00:04:00.950 --> 00:04:03.910
We really looked at this data
sheet form inside the Form Wizard.

85
00:04:03.910 --> 00:04:08.440
The Split Form's a little bit more
unusual, it says creates a split form

86
00:04:08.440 --> 00:04:13.440
that shoes data sheet in the upper section
and a form in the lower one instead.

87
00:04:13.440 --> 00:04:15.390
So this is actually something
that's very good for

88
00:04:15.390 --> 00:04:19.700

do that data entry at the same time.

89
00:04:19.700 --> 00:04:20.810
They enter it in the form and

90
00:04:20.810 --> 00:04:25.500
they watch the actual data appear in
that data sheet view at the top, then,

91
00:04:25.500 --> 00:04:28.480
they know that it actually got entered in
and they're doing stuff like that as well.

92
00:04:28.480 --> 00:04:32.910
>> It almost has two different views,
the entry view and

93
00:04:32.910 --> 00:04:36.496
the result of what it's
>> Kind of like what we use for markdown-

94
00:04:36.496 --> 00:04:37.720
>> For the preview.

95
00:04:37.720 --> 00:04:40.290
>> Yeah.

96
00:04:40.290 --> 00:04:41.690
That makes sense.

97
00:04:41.690 --> 00:04:43.680
>> And
then you have an interactive one too.

98
00:04:43.680 --> 00:04:48.400
Setting up the modal dialog takes a little
bit longer for you to be able to do.

99
00:04:48.400 --> 00:04:49.530
It is possible.

100
00:04:49.530 --> 00:04:51.370
This is just more interactive.

101
00:04:51.370 --> 00:04:55.670
It has different pop ups or different,
and make sure you answer questions so

102
00:04:55.670 --> 00:04:56.990
that you end up getting what you want to.

103
00:04:56.990 --> 00:04:59.940
And we used to call this
a parameterized view as well.

104
00:04:59.940 --> 00:05:03.760
>> And I'm still stuck back on
the navigation one of like I'm envisioning

105
00:05:03.760 --> 00:05:10.530
buttons and some colors and so you could

So this gives us this ability

We do have to use a combination,

And if I want a new record,

Now, Vonne, there's actually a bit

I just realized again,

570
00:28:27.370 --> 00:28:29.169
>> [LAUGH]
>> And that means we need to do a little

571

bit more cuz there's more on formatting,
definitely a lot more that we wanna show,

572

but will not have time for
it this episode.

573
00:28:35.150 --> 00:28:39.370
>> Well, when you added that label in,

I'm also assuming that the ones it added

575

>> Because maybe the field name doesn't

I'm seeing this is right down my alley

It was already starting to annoy me,

579

Those aren't lined up.

That needs to be a little bit longer.

583

>> [LAUGH]
>> Let me move that over and

587

But I want to let the master do his work,
>> [LAUGH]

588

>> So, but thank you so much, and

thank you for all my questions,

But what is going to happen is we're

episodes.description: Vonne and Ronnie wrap up the Access forms miniseries by demonstrating some key layout and design formatting.  They show how to align and distribute form elements, explore the layout view, and add a combo box control.
episodes.title: Creating Basic Forms Part 4

episodes.description: Ronnie and Vonne introduce us to reports in Access. They discuss the importance of good reports to summarize and display the information in your database.
episodes.title: Creating Basic Reports
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

[MUSIC]

2

Hello, everyone and welcome to another

this is the Access 2016 Essentials show.

And we are specifically talking about

5

And here to help us with this is Mr.
Ronnie Wong.

6

Hello.
How are you?

7
00:00:29.552 --> 00:00:31.235
[LAUGH]
>> I am doing fine Vonne.

8

Once again back here at OfficePro Studios
and ready to actually get started and

9
00:00:36.700 --> 00:00:40.360
one of our final sections
in taking look at access.

10

Remember that what we've actually
covered so far is not only of course

understanding the basics
of database design.

12
00:00:48.360 --> 00:00:52.280
We didn't really jumped super deep into

13

We also showed you where you could take
that information and create the tables,

14
00:00:56.360 --> 00:00:58.605
the structures that's gonna
hold your information.

15
00:00:58.605 --> 00:01:01.434
Allowed you to also see
clearing the information

16
00:01:01.434 --> 00:01:05.505
that you can verify that your design
is correct as well as be able to pull

17
00:01:05.505 --> 00:01:08.688
the information out of your
database that you need to.

18

And then we also, of course,
created different forms, and

00:01:12.373 --> 00:01:16.150
now we are into the aspects
of talking about reports.

20
00:01:16.150 --> 00:01:19.800
So that is what we're actually taking
a look at is this idea of actually

21

that exist in our database, okay?

22
00:01:25.280 --> 00:01:30.190
So, Vonne, when we start to take a look
at this particular aspect of it,

23
00:01:30.190 --> 00:01:32.930
it is actually something that sounds easy.

24
00:01:32.930 --> 00:01:37.905
Most of us have dealt with reports before,
when we've all seen them but

25
00:01:37.905 --> 00:01:41.630
Vonne we've also seen bad reports as well,
okay?

26
00:01:41.630 --> 00:01:45.286
So that's why we want to make sure
that we understand when we talk

27
00:01:45.286 --> 00:01:49.315
about building reports that we need
to actually build good reports.

28
00:01:49.315 --> 00:01:51.695
And that's what Access can help us to do.

29
00:01:51.695 --> 00:01:55.295
>> So Ronnie, like you just said,
we have the questions with the query.

30
00:01:55.295 --> 00:01:58.265
We had the input, which was the forms.

31
00:01:58.265 --> 00:01:59.525
>> Right.
>> And now we're doing

32

the output which is the reports.

33
00:02:01.325 --> 00:02:04.193
It's like your bosses come up to you and
said okay,

34
