I'd love to have that TPS report.

35
00:02:06.147 --> 00:02:09.220
>> [LAUGH]
>> If you could have it by Friday that'll

36
00:02:09.220 --> 00:02:09.820
be great.

37
00:02:09.820 --> 00:02:13.090
I know, yes, that's a lame joke but
I can't help it, it's so

38
00:02:13.090 --> 00:02:14.720
awesome, it's iconic.

39
00:02:14.720 --> 00:02:18.340
But that's really where we're at,
we're making a blah, blah,

40
00:02:18.340 --> 00:02:20.175
blah report, TPS report.

41
00:02:20.175 --> 00:02:22.860
[LAUGH]
>> There's no doubt that this is what ends

42
00:02:22.860 --> 00:02:24.270
up happening, kay Vonne?

43
00:02:24.270 --> 00:02:29.100
So most of the people end up using some
type of relational database system.

44
00:02:29.100 --> 00:02:33.090
They understand that they generate
reports but they may not understand why

45
00:02:33.090 --> 00:02:36.110
the reports are generated
the way that they are generated.

46
00:02:36.110 --> 00:02:39.480
And that can lead to some confusion,
because a lot of times you

47
00:02:39.480 --> 00:02:43.760
hand this report and you look at it and
you like, what is this telling me?

48
00:02:43.760 --> 00:02:45.740
And that's were the real issue comes in.

49
00:02:45.740 --> 00:02:49.150
What we need to be able to do is we need
to understand not only have access to

50
00:02:49.150 --> 00:02:54.050
helps us to generate reports, but also why
we actually need good reports as well.

51
00:02:54.050 --> 00:02:55.800
>> Yes.
Like we're getting the answer but

52
00:02:55.800 --> 00:02:59.105
the answer doesn't make any sense.

53
00:02:59.105 --> 00:03:01.030
[LAUGH] And I've had that before.

54
00:03:01.030 --> 00:03:04.750
I have all this and
what does this actually mean?

55
00:03:04.750 --> 00:03:05.790
>> Right.
>> And

56
00:03:05.790 --> 00:03:11.230
if you have to kind of explain your way
through your report and your answer,

57
00:03:12.260 --> 00:03:17.060
that's where the proper, not just
formatting but just making sure you

58
00:03:17.060 --> 00:03:20.500
add all the elements that are needed and
so on and so forth so yeah.

59
00:03:20.500 --> 00:03:22.510
Clear reporting would be very good.

60
00:03:22.510 --> 00:03:27.150
>> Yeah, the kind of worst comment about
your report is not that it's a bad report,

61
00:03:27.150 --> 00:03:28.766
I know that sounds weird, right?

62
00:03:28.766 --> 00:03:32.670
Because bad report can mean, hey we
got data and it doesn't look good for

63
00:03:32.670 --> 00:03:34.580
us, and that seems to make sense.

64
00:03:34.580 --> 00:03:36.670
But is when you hand
the report to somebody and

65
00:03:36.670 --> 00:03:39.790
they ask you, what does this data mean?

66
00:03:39.790 --> 00:03:44.440
Well, your report should be indicating
what that data means without you having to

67
00:03:44.440 --> 00:03:49.970
really explain it too much, besides maybe
a title on your report that you have.

68
00:03:49.970 --> 00:03:51.780
It should need much more explanation.

69
00:03:51.780 --> 00:03:55.240
Now don't get me wrong,
people ask for clarification.

70
00:03:55.240 --> 00:03:59.170
But overall though, the report
should say what needs to be said.

71
00:03:59.170 --> 00:04:02.980
So what are some examples that we're
talking about in terms of reports that can

72
00:04:02.980 --> 00:04:05.100
really be overwhelming.

73
00:04:05.100 --> 00:04:12.040
Well, one is that you get a report and
it has too much data in it.

74
00:04:12.040 --> 00:04:15.340
So when somebody hands you that report and
you're expected to see one or

75
00:04:15.340 --> 00:04:18.980
two pages, and it turns out to be
ten pages long, you're a little

76
00:04:18.980 --> 00:04:23.270
bit more overwhelmed by that,
because you start to realize something.

77
00:04:23.270 --> 00:04:27.270
You're not gonna find the information
that you need in what you expected so

78
00:04:27.270 --> 00:04:28.970
they're gonna make you dig for

79
00:04:28.970 --> 00:04:32.680
the information through ten pages of
this report that they've handed you.

80
00:04:32.680 --> 00:04:35.390
And more than likely that means
that they've handed you too much

81
00:04:35.390 --> 00:04:36.920
information, okay?

82
00:04:36.920 --> 00:04:41.010
And the reason behind that is because
people that end up writing reports

83
00:04:41.010 --> 00:04:46.010
a lot of times, they don't understand what
the end result is supposed to do for them.

84
00:04:46.010 --> 00:04:48.830
So we're gonna talk about that in a little
bit when we were designing the reports

85
00:04:48.830 --> 00:04:50.790
that we're actually gonna design.

86
00:04:50.790 --> 00:04:55.530
Also, if they give you data
that seems to be extraneous,

87
00:04:55.530 --> 00:04:59.530
let's say for example that you end
up taking a look at your report, and

88
00:04:59.530 --> 00:05:03.580
you start to wonder why is this
particular field being reported on.

89
00:05:03.580 --> 00:05:06.610
The person handing out the report,
the person explaining it,

90
00:05:06.610 --> 00:05:10.505
didn't even address it in the whole time
that they were talking about the report.

91
00:05:10.505 --> 00:05:13.720
Well when you have something like that,
right, you gotta realize that somebody

92
00:05:13.720 --> 00:05:16.950
ended up putting that in there,
thinking that it might be addressed.

93
00:05:16.950 --> 00:05:20.500
But data without context
is essentially meaningless.

94
00:05:20.500 --> 00:05:25.380
So adding in meaningless data is
just about as overwhelming as it

95
00:05:25.380 --> 00:05:30.530
is when you actually have too much data
being displayed in the report as well.

96
00:05:30.530 --> 00:05:35.124
So, we need to learn how to kind of filter
out some of the information that we don't

97
00:05:35.124 --> 00:05:36.730
want showing up too, okay.

98
00:05:36.730 --> 00:05:40.790
The other thing that can end up happening
is that you give the wrong report to

99
00:05:40.790 --> 00:05:42.410
the wrong person.

100
00:05:42.410 --> 00:05:45.280
Now it doesn't mean that they
didn't ask for that information.

101
00:05:45.280 --> 00:05:48.470
But it means that you didn't
understand who your particular

102
00:05:48.470 --> 00:05:50.670
audience ended up being.

103
00:05:50.670 --> 00:05:54.960
So now they're looking at information
that may be relevant to them but

104
00:05:54.960 --> 00:05:58.420
they didn't actually understand
what was handed to them.

105
00:05:58.420 --> 00:06:00.960
So it would be something like this.

106
00:06:00.960 --> 00:06:05.290
Now where we work, we are highly
technical in everything that we do,

107
00:06:05.290 --> 00:06:10.550
whether we're where we are, or whether
I should talking about our CEO as well.

108
00:06:10.550 --> 00:06:13.080
He can understand a lot of
the things that we might say and do.

109
00:06:13.080 --> 00:06:18.700
But if I actually had someone that didn't
have that background or the technology and

110
00:06:18.700 --> 00:06:23.150
stuff, if I handed them a report that had
all these technical figures in it and

111
00:06:23.150 --> 00:06:26.500
talked all this information and
the data points and all that.

112
00:06:26.500 --> 00:06:28.680
He might look at me like
I didn't need this,

113
00:06:28.680 --> 00:06:33.760
I just really needed what I needed and
not all this other stuff.

114
00:06:33.760 --> 00:06:35.890
That's why we have to be very careful.

115
00:06:35.890 --> 00:06:39.740
>> Philip, somebody that worked for
this here our company.

116
00:06:39.740 --> 00:06:43.820
He gets into all these different
numbers of terms and burns, and

117
00:06:43.820 --> 00:06:46.040
he's using a lot of jargon,
showing me all this stuff.

118
00:06:46.040 --> 00:06:50.194
And I was like wait, so
how many members do we have?

119
00:06:50.194 --> 00:06:54.250
[LAUGH] It's one of those, but that's
very specific to what he is showing.

120
00:06:54.250 --> 00:06:56.180
He's showing you all these figures.

121
00:06:56.180 --> 00:06:58.830
You just wanted to see how
many total members we have or

122
00:06:58.830 --> 00:07:03.510
how many total number we have for
this month, those types of things.

123
00:07:03.510 --> 00:07:05.170
I think that's kind of like the scope.

124
00:07:05.170 --> 00:07:06.934
>> Yeah.
We're talking about scope,

125
00:07:06.934 --> 00:07:11.080
create before and target audience,
all of those different things.

126
00:07:11.080 --> 00:07:14.760
Or this is more of
the theoretical part of forms but

127
00:07:14.760 --> 00:07:18.410
it's extremely important cuz,
well you're in an office setting and

128
00:07:18.410 --> 00:07:22.430
you need to make sure that you have all
of these parts when you're doing them.

129
00:07:22.430 --> 00:07:25.693
>> It's more important than we realized
because if we start off with not

130
00:07:25.693 --> 00:07:29.523
understanding who are audience is we'll
more than likely either overwhelm them

131
00:07:29.523 --> 00:07:32.676
with the information or
they'll take a look at the information and

132
00:07:32.676 --> 00:07:34.720
not understand what is there.

133
00:07:34.720 --> 00:07:37.750
So having a solid understanding
of this is actually what helped

134
00:07:37.750 --> 00:07:42.380
you to develop a good report in the end
of what you also need to be able to do.

135
00:07:42.380 --> 00:07:44.460
>> And it's kinda like,
just because you know your data,

136
00:07:44.460 --> 00:07:47.958
doesn't mean somebody else
knows the data the same way.

137
00:07:47.958 --> 00:07:51.312
I mean, cuz if you're going to
be in access and developing and

138
00:07:51.312 --> 00:07:55.454
building the things that we're going
through the queries and everything.

139
00:07:55.454 --> 00:07:59.866
You're gonna have a much more intimate
relationship with this data so

140
00:07:59.866 --> 00:08:04.664
you're gonna know it really well and
the other people they don't see that.

141
00:08:04.664 --> 00:08:07.702
Just the same with Philip,
knowing all about our sales and

142
00:08:07.702 --> 00:08:09.635
that kind of aspect of the business.

143
00:08:09.635 --> 00:08:13.020
Where we are not really
associated with that.

144
00:08:13.020 --> 00:08:17.800
So it's just to each its own, but
make sure it's translatable [LAUGH].

145
00:08:17.800 --> 00:08:18.390
>> Yeah.
And

146
00:08:18.390 --> 00:08:22.750
that target is really important for
what we want to be able to understand.

147
00:08:22.750 --> 00:08:27.010
And of course that means that we also have
to focus in on the purpose of our report

148
00:08:27.010 --> 00:08:28.050
as well.

149
00:08:28.050 --> 00:08:31.910
Now, the idea of purpose is
very important in the end.

150
00:08:31.910 --> 00:08:35.650
We can pull out whatever numbers
that we want to from our data.

151
00:08:35.650 --> 00:08:37.510
I guarantee you you can do it.

152
00:08:37.510 --> 00:08:42.150
You can also take the data and
manipulate it to show what you want to do

153
00:08:42.150 --> 00:08:45.200
by using some advanced filtering
if you choose to do that.

154
00:08:45.200 --> 00:08:48.743
You can even make somebody look
bad if you want to as well, okay?

155
00:08:48.743 --> 00:08:51.100
So all that can be done.

156
00:08:51.100 --> 00:08:56.010
But in the end, you have to know what
the purpose of your report is gonna be.

157
00:08:56.010 --> 00:09:01.350
The majority of times when someone is
asking for a report, for a database,

158
00:09:01.350 --> 00:09:06.030
it usually is not just simple
curiosity that ends up happening.

159
00:09:06.030 --> 00:09:11.880
But it is because somebody is trying
to make business decisions based off of

160
00:09:11.880 --> 00:09:17.440
the data that they are looking to take or
they are trying to take a look at, okay?

161
00:09:17.440 --> 00:09:21.530
So in other words, it's very important
that we present the right data,

162
00:09:21.530 --> 00:09:25.630
in the right format,
at the right time of everything.

163
00:09:25.630 --> 00:09:29.700
So that what can be presented at
that point is accurate data, so

164
00:09:29.700 --> 00:09:36.180
that they can make good solid business
decisions based off of that report.

165
00:09:36.180 --> 00:09:39.420
And when they can't do that
because the report is wrong,

166
00:09:39.420 --> 00:09:41.810
it's not that the data and
the figures are wrong.

167
00:09:41.810 --> 00:09:46.130
It's that the report that's generated is
one of those things that we talked about.

168
00:09:46.130 --> 00:09:50.680
And that's why it's very important that we
at least have that solid understanding of

169
00:09:50.680 --> 00:09:56.900
working in terms of building a good report
when we're asked to build this report.

170
00:09:56.900 --> 00:10:02.090
So this is one of those things where
working with the forms as we did before

171
00:10:02.090 --> 00:10:04.330
helps us tremendously, okay?

172
00:10:04.330 --> 00:10:05.700
Because building a form and

173
00:10:05.700 --> 00:10:12.230
building report is not super different
in terms of layout in some measures.

174
00:10:12.230 --> 00:10:16.810
But when we get into how the data's
gonna be displayed, you're gonna see

175
00:10:16.810 --> 00:10:21.000
that is gonna be much more different
than what we think it's going to be.

176
00:10:21.000 --> 00:10:24.707
So it's important that we
understand that as we get started.

177
00:10:24.707 --> 00:10:29.430
So don't overlook this fact of the few
minutes that we've been talking here and

178
00:10:29.430 --> 00:10:33.167
discussing the idea why is it
important that we need reports and

179
00:10:33.167 --> 00:10:34.380
why we use reports.

180
00:10:34.380 --> 00:10:38.028
Because if we overlook this and just
think I'm just gonna build my reports,

181
00:10:38.028 --> 00:10:41.904
if you do get that comment, I don't know
what this data is telling me, unless you

182
00:10:41.904 --> 00:10:45.666
haven't built it correctly, so go back and
take a look at those situations and

our foreshadowing and

411
00:22:38.501 --> 00:22:42.504
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Vonne and Ronnie show how to create reports. They create mailing labels, use the report button, start from a blank report, and walk through the report wizard. They also show how to modify report layouts in the layout view.
episodes.title: Creating Basic Reports Part 2
episodes.transcript:

episodes.description: Vonne and Ronnie are back with more reports in Access. In this episode, they explore creating a report in the design view (banded report writer). They explain the different sections of the banded report writer and how to summarize data with the group and sort command.
episodes.title: Creating Basic Reports Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne dive deeper into building reports in design view. They demonstrate what happens when you add a field into a report that does not have a relationship established to the current report.  They show how to create a calculated field with expression builder as well as summarize data in the section footer. Finally, they begin to build a query as an alternative way to create a report.
episodes.title: Creating Basic Reports Part 4

episodes.description: In this final episode, Ronnie and Vonne create a report from a table created from a query. They show us how to create a concatenated field in the query to ultimately create a section header in the report. They also review how to align and format fields as well as change background colors of the different sections.
episodes.title: Creating Basic Reports Part 5
